name: Pronoun
definition: A pronoun is a word used to replace a noun or another pronoun to avoid repetition and make sentences flow smoothly.
importance: Pronouns are essential for creating natural, flowing conversations and writing. They help avoid repetitive use of nouns while maintaining clarity about who or what we're talking about.
tagline: Replace nouns, reduce repetition, improve flow!

types.name: Personal Pronouns
types.description: Pronouns that refer to specific people or things. They change form based on whether they are the subject or object of a sentence.

types.name: Possessive Pronouns
types.description: Pronouns that show ownership or belonging. They indicate that something belongs to someone.

types.name: Reflexive Pronouns
types.description: Pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. They are used when the subject and object are the same.

types.name: Relative Pronouns
types.description: Pronouns that introduce relative clauses and connect them to the main clause. They refer to a noun mentioned before.

rules.title: DO: Use Correct Person and Number
points: Use 'I' for yourself, 'you' for the other person, 'he/she/it' for singular, 'we/they' for plural
Match the pronoun to the noun it replaces: 'The students studied hard. They passed the exam.'
Use 'we' when speaking about a group including yourself
examples: ‚úÖ Maria is a teacher. She loves her job.
‚úÖ The books are on the shelf. They are interesting.
‚úÖ John and I went to the movies. We enjoyed it.

rules.title: DO: Use Subject Pronouns Correctly
points: Use subject pronouns (I, you, he, she, it, we, they) as the subject of a sentence
Use subject pronouns after linking verbs like 'is', 'am', 'are'
Remember: subject pronouns perform the action

rules.title: DON'T: Mix Up Subject and Object Pronouns
points: Don't use object pronouns (me, you, him, her, it, us, them) as the subject of a sentence
Don't say 'Me and John went to school' - it should be 'John and I went to school'
Remember: object pronouns receive the action
examples: ‚ùå Me and her went shopping. ‚Üí ‚úÖ She and I went shopping.
‚ùå Him is a doctor. ‚Üí ‚úÖ He is a doctor.
‚ùå They gave it to she. ‚Üí ‚úÖ They gave it to her.

rules.title: DON'T: Use Reflexive Pronouns Incorrectly
points: Don't use reflexive pronouns instead of personal pronouns
Reflexive pronouns should only refer back to the subject
Don't say 'between you and myself' - say 'between you and me'
examples: ‚ùå He hurt himself yesterday. (If he didn't do it to himself) ‚Üí ‚úÖ He hurt him yesterday.
‚ùå Send it to John and myself. ‚Üí ‚úÖ Send it to John and me.
‚ùå Myself and John are friends. ‚Üí ‚úÖ John and I are friends.

rules.title: DO: Use Possessive Pronouns Correctly
points: Use possessive pronouns to show ownership without using a noun after them
Possessive pronouns don't have apostrophes (avoid 'his', use 'his')
examples: ‚úÖ This book is mine. (Not: This is mine book)

examples.sentence: Sarah loves reading. She reads every evening.
I gave him my number, and he called me.
examples.usage_pattern: Multiple pronouns showing subjects and objects

examples.sentence: The book is hers; the pen is mine.
She hurt herself when she fell.
The student who won the prize is talented.
You and I should work together.
The teacher, whom we respect, retired yesterday.

exercises.title: Rewrite Using Pronouns
exercises.prompt:
Rewrite the following paragraph using appropriate pronouns to replace repeated nouns:

John is a software engineer. John works at a tech company. John's company is very successful. John and his colleagues developed a new app. The app is used by millions of people. Many people use the app every day.
exercises.sample_answer: John is a software engineer. He works at a tech company. His company is very successful. He and his colleagues developed a new app. It is used by millions of people. Many use it every day.

exercises.title: Identify and Correct Pronoun Errors
exercises.passage: Lisa and me went to the movies yesterday. We watched a film that were really entertaining. The actors in it was fantastic. Between you and myself, I think it was the best movie I've seen. Lisa, who I like very much, sat next to I. Her enjoyed it too. The ending surprised we all.
exercises.sample_answer: Lisa and I went to the movies yesterday. We watched a film that was really entertaining. The actors in it were fantastic. Between you and me, I think it was the best movie I've seen. Lisa, who I like very much, sat next to me. She enjoyed it too. The ending surprised us all.

common_mistakes.error: Me and my friend went shopping.
common_mistakes.correct: My friend and I went shopping.
common_mistakes.explanation: Use subject pronouns (I) for the subject of a sentence, not object pronouns (me). Also, put the other person first as a matter of courtesy.

common_mistakes.error: She gave the book to John and me.
common_mistakes.correct: She gave the book to John and me.
common_mistakes.explanation: This is actually correct! Use object pronouns after prepositions like 'to'.

common_mistakes.error: Between you and I, this is secret.
common_mistakes.correct: Between you and me, this is secret.
common_mistakes.explanation: After prepositions like 'between', use object pronouns (me), not subject pronouns (I).
Use the correct reflexive pronoun form. 'Theirself' doesn't exist; use 'themselves' for plural.

common_mistakes.error: Who did you talk to? ‚Üí It was me.
common_mistakes.correct: Who did you talk to? ‚Üí It was I. (formal) or It was me. (informal)
common_mistakes.explanation: Technically, after linking verbs like 'was', use subject pronouns. However, 'It was me' is widely accepted in informal speech.

common_mistakes.error: That is the woman which helped me.
common_mistakes.correct: That is the woman who helped me.
common_mistakes.explanation: 'Who' refers to people; 'which' refers to things. 'That' can refer to either.

common_mistakes.error: Myself and Sarah are going to the party.
common_mistakes.correct: Sarah and I are going to the party.
common_mistakes.explanation: Don't use reflexive pronouns as subjects. Use 'I' instead of 'myself'.

common_mistakes.error: The book is hers'. It has hers name in it.
common_mistakes.correct: The book is hers. It has her name in it.
common_mistakes.explanation: Possessive pronouns don't have apostrophes. 'Hers' means 'belonging to her'; 'her' modifies the noun 'name'.

quick_facts: English has 10 main subject pronouns: I, you, he, she, it, we, they (and archaic thou, ye)
Object pronouns are: me, you, him, her, it, us, them
Reflexive pronouns always end in '-self' or '-selves'
Pronouns are one of the most frequently used words in English
The word 'they' can now be used as a singular pronoun for non-binary people
Possessive pronouns never need apostrophes (its, not it's for possession)
'Who' is for subjects; 'whom' is for objects (though 'whom' is becoming less common)
Relative pronouns introduce dependent clauses that describe nouns
